Entry.2: Received three letters from Mother & one from Cis Robinson
Entry.6:
received three letters from Mother one enclosed from J Kempley, 10/- enclosed from Mater.

Register package for WKF 5 p.t. stamps for G. Bluman
Entry.7:
Received three letters

1 from J Kempley
Entry.12:
Received letter from Cis R in Caufield, Melbourne

Practically our first experience of rain in Egypt occurred today. About four pm. Light showers commenced which abated 
until
 about 5 pm. Light showers at 4 am.
Entry.13:
commenced raining in real earnest. At 7 am however, it

had cleared again, but sky very cloudy. 9.15am commenced raining once more, abating at 12 n.
Entry.14: Replied to Cis R. to Melbourne PD
Entry.17:
wrote to J Kempley

Mrs Evans

Ap. 4th wrote to mother from Alexandria and sent views & cards
Entry.19:
A&B Cos. leave Mena, en route on foot to Cairo. Left camp 7.30 pm arrived station about midnight

 Easter Sunday
Entry.20:
2.30 am train leaves for Alexandria which place was reached at 8 am.

Embarkation on Derrflinger immediately. The latter ship by the way was one of the armed German merchantman recently captured by

the British. Ship’s external appearance very dirty & unattractive. However, passenger’s quarters very well accomodated, & officers made very comfortable.
Entry.21:
Derrflinger still moored to wharf & crew & fatigue parties of troops busy taking on stores, ammunition etc. 10am No. 3 Platoon A. Co. Mount Guard

The Derrflinger is to be used in transporting 2nd & 3rd Battalions & is naturally very crowded. At 6.30 pm weigh anchor & leave harbour. Light sea running.
Entry.22:
Stiff breez blowing all day. Sea pretty choppy.

Majority of troops suffer from sea sickness.

No land in sight.
Entry.23:
Still windy. Land sighted at day break on Starboard side.

Presume we are in the Grecian Archipelago. All signs of sea sickness vanished, with the exception of scuppers not washed out. Ship’s crew mostly Dagos, who try to dispose of fruit, cigarettes, etc. at extortionate rates.

10 am ‘A" CO get issued with 200 rounds ammunition, pay books handed in &

fixed up for pay at 2 pm.

Land still in sight on both sides (Islands). Paid £2.
Entry.24:
9 am Paid an extra £1.

Enter harbour & anchor at 9 am, almost surrounded by land. Many other Transports at anchor & several men-of-war cruising round. Not sure whether mainland or islands. Apparently the latter. Day beautiful & warm, sea like a lake. Russian Cruiser at anchor close by. Same ship in Colombo when Euripides was outward bound from Australia.

Having become possessors of gold once more, troops indulge in gambling. Though only paid yesterday, many are penniless already.

Thursday (cont’d)

At about sunset, two more men-of-war enter harbour, one apparently damaged.
Entry.25: Awake to find several more ships in harbour, transports & men-of-war. The cruiser we took to be damaged, leaves about 8 am. Dull morning. All hands on board eagerly awaiting time when we shall leave Derrflinger. Lower decks very stuffy & overcrowded. No more meat to be issued on board. This necessitates troops living on biscuits, cheese & jam, with a bread issue once daily.
Entry.26: Very windy. More transports enter harbour.
Entry.27: Nice weather. Hydroplane evidently attached to one of men-of-war in harbour, soars over island & finally alights in water close to cruiser.
Entry.28: 12 am receive Dad’s letter telling of mother’s illness which he says Dr Martin reports as very serious. Had this letter reached me in Cairo, I was then in a position to write or even cable a reply, but living in Lemnos island without permission to send other than the F.S. postcards, one naturally feels it more acutely. May God grant my dear mother will be spared to see the kiddies reared. S.S. “Armadale" moors to “Derrflinger". Receive 2 let. from Cis & one from Mother.
Entry.29: 7.45 am A Co. practise leaving ship in boats. 10 am steady rain sets in.
Entry.30: All hands leave Derrflinger in naval launches & cutters being towed ashore by pinnace. Carry out short skirmish on Island. Natives very clean looking & all houses built of stone.
Entry.31: Feel out o’ sorts & don’t attend afternoon parades.
Entry.32:
Weigh anchor at six a.m. & steam out of harbour under escort.

Wrote to mother
Entry.35: Applied to Agent General for N S.W. for £20 of my Sydney bank account.
Entry.36:
Money received in £1 notes.

Handed over to Mrs Hilder £20
Entry.37:
Received news of my chum J Vitish more than delighted to hear that, after five months on Gallipoli was uninjured and doing well.

Jan. 27

Drew £4 pounds of sum deposited with Mrs Hilder.
